clean_content:
Definition / general

* Benign, rare tumor of odontogenic origin* Cuboidal to columnar ameloblastic epithelium that forms duct-like structures, epithelial whorls and cribriform architecture; dentinoid deposits, clusters of clear cells and ghost cell keratinization may also be present ([J Oral Maxillofac Pathol 2012;16:272](22923903))

Essential features

* Adenoid ameloblastomas have a predilection for the posterior mandible ([Head Neck Pathol 2022;16:344](34282559))* Microscopically, adenoid ameloblastomas consist of epithelium resembling conventional ameloblastoma in addition to duct-like structures, epithelial whorls and cribriform architecture* Dentinoid deposits, clusters of clear cells and ghost cell keratinization may also be observed ([J Oral Maxillofac Pathol 2012;16:272](22923903))* Adenoid ameloblastoma can be a challenging and controversial diagnosis as this tumor has features seen in numerous odontogenic tumors (i.e., ameloblastoma, adenomatoid odontogenic tumor, calcifying odontogenic cyst / dentinogenic ghost cell tumor and odontogenic carcinoma with dentinoid)

Terminology

* Adenoid ameloblastoma with dentinoid was proposed by Brannon of the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology in 1994; this terminology has been deemed acceptable by the World Health Organization (WHO) ([Brannon: Adenoid Ameloblastoma With Dentinoid, 1994](https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Adenoid+ameloblastoma+with+dentinoid&author=RB+Brannon&publication_year=1994&))* Described as dentinoameloblastoma by Slabbert et al. in 1992 ([J Oral Pathol Med 1992;21:46](1593496))

ICD coding

* ICD-O: [9300/0](https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/96612/9789241548496_eng.pdf?sequence=1#page=89) - adenoid ameloblastoma* ICD-10
    + [D16.4](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/D10-D36/D16-/D16.4) - benign neoplasm of skull and face+ [D16.5](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/D10-D36/D16-/D16.5) - benign neoplasm of lower jaw bone* ICD-11
      + [2E83.0 & XH1SV4](https://icd.who.int/browse11/l-m/en#/http%3a%2f%2fid.who.int%2ficd%2fentity%2f1486607775?data=%7B%22dataType%22%3A%22pc%22%2C%22postcoordinationCodeSet%22%3A%7B%22stemId%22%3A%22http%3A%2F%2Fid.who.int%2Ficd%2Fentity%2F1486607775%22%2C%22axisToValueIds%22%3A%7B%22specificAnatomy%22%3A%5B%7B%22stemId%22%3A%22http%3A%2F%2Fid.who.int%2Ficd%2Fentity%2F92385094%22%7D%5D%7D%7D%7D) - benign osteogenic tumors of bone or articular cartilage of skull or face & ameloblastoma, NOS+ [2E83.1 & XH1SV4](https://icd.who.int/browse11/l-m/en#/http%3a%2f%2fid.who.int%2ficd%2fentity%2f1037047819?data=%7B%22dataType%22%3A%22pc%22%2C%22postcoordinationCodeSet%22%3A%7B%22stemId%22%3A%22http%3A%2F%2Fid.who.int%2Ficd%2Fentity%2F1037047819%22%2C%22axisToValueIds%22%3A%7B%22histopathology%22%3A%5B%7B%22stemId%22%3A%22http%3A%2F%2Fid.who.int%2Ficd%2Fentity%2F92385094%22%7D%5D%7D%7D%7D) - benign osteogenic tumors of bone or articular cartilage of lower jaw & ameloblastoma, NOS

Epidemiology

* Occurrence peaks in the fourth decade, with a slight male predilection (M:F = 1.3:1) and a wide age range of 15 - 82 years ([Head Neck Pathol 2022;16:344](34282559))

Sites

* ~64.7% of adenoid ameloblastomas occur in the mandible ([Head Neck Pathol 2022;16:344](34282559))
  + Posterior gnathic bones are most commonly affected ([Head Neck Pathol 2023;17:688](37540485))

Etiology

* Unknown

Clinical features

* Usually an asymptomatic swelling (unless secondarily infected)* Tooth displacement may be present

Diagnosis

* Adenoid ameloblastoma may be detected radiographically as an incidental finding or present as a clinical swelling

Radiology description

* 82.4% of adenoid ameloblastomas present exclusively as radiolucent lesions and may be ill defined ([Head Neck Pathol 2022;16:344](34282559))
  + May also appear as mixed density due to the presence of dentinoid* May be unilocular or multilocular

Radiology images

*Images hosted on other servers:*  

[![Diffuse periapical radiolucency](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/thumb/mandiblemaxillaadenoidameloblastomanih01.jpg)](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3424947/figure/F2/)

Diffuse periapical radiolucency

Prognostic factors

* 45.4% of adenoid ameloblastomas developed at least 1 recurrence following surgical excision ([Head Neck Pathol 2022;16:344](34282559))

Case reports

* 39 year old man with a chief concern of painful, mobile teeth in the right posterior maxilla ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2019;128:E53](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.oooo.2019.02.116))* 54 year old woman with asymptomatic radiolucency of the left posterior maxilla ([Oral Maxillofac Surg 2020;24:243](31925581))* 57 year old woman with a well defined, unilocular radiolucency between the roots of the right mandibular premolars without intraoral changes ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2022;134:E162](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.oooo.2022.01.436))

Treatment

* Conventional treatment consists of surgical resection as primary therapy ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2015;120:368](26297394))
  + Patients may also receive radiotherapy as adjuvant to prevent recurrence ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2015;120:368](26297394))

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Epithelium resembling conventional ameloblastoma, particularly palisading of cells at peripheries of the tumor nests, with additional duct-like structures and cribriform architecture* Basophilic areas of cellular condensation or morules may be present* Dentinoid deposits, clusters of clear cells and ghost cell keratinization may also be observed ([J Oral Maxillofac Pathol 2012;16:272](22923903))* Mitotic activity may be increased ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2019;128:e78](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.oooo.2019.02.196), [Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2015;120:368](26297394))

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Elizabeth Ann Bilodeau, D.M.D., M.D., M.S.Ed.   

[![Epithelial whorls](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaadenoidameloblastomaBilodeau01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaadenoidameloblastomaBilodeau01.jpg)

Epithelial whorls

[![Cribriform architecture and eosinophilic matrix](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaadenoidameloblastomaBilodeau02.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaadenoidameloblastomaBilodeau02.jpg)

Cribriform architecture and eosinophilic matrix

[![Focal ghost cell keratinization](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaadenoidameloblastomaBilodeau03.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaadenoidameloblastomaBilodeau03.jpg)

Focal ghost cell keratinization

[![Dentinoid deposits](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaadenoidameloblastomaBilodeau04.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaadenoidameloblastomaBilodeau04.jpg)

Dentinoid deposits

[![Increased mitotic activity](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaadenoidameloblastomaBilodeau05.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaadenoidameloblastomaBilodeau05.jpg)

Increased mitotic activity

[![Duct-like structures and ghost cell keratinization](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaadenoidameloblastomaBilodeau06.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillaadenoidameloblastomaBilodeau06.jpg)

Duct-like structures and ghost cell keratinization

Positive stains

* [AE1 / AE3](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsae1ae3.html) ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2019;128:e78](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.oooo.2019.02.196))* [Beta catenin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsbetacatenin.html) within morules ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2019;128:e78](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.oooo.2019.02.196))* [CK5/6](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck5and6.html) ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2019;128:e78](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.oooo.2019.02.196))* [Ki67](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainski67.html) may have variable expression, with the upper limit being 72.4 plus or minus 24.9 positive cells per high power field ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2015;120:368](26297394))* [p63](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsp63.html) and [p40](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsp40.html) are positive ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2019;128:e78](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.oooo.2019.02.196))* [p16](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsp16.html) is variable ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2015;120:368](26297394), [Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2019;128:e78](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.oooo.2019.02.196))

Negative stains

* [BRAF V600E](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsbraf.html)* [CK7](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck7.html)* [p53](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsp53.html)* [SMA](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsalphasmoothmuscleactin.html)* [SOX10](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainssox10.html)* [S100](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainss100.html)* Reference: [Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2019;128:e78](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.oooo.2019.02.196)

Molecular / cytogenetics description

* *BRAF* p.V600E mutation (which is observed in other ameloblastomas) in addition to *KRAS* p.G12V and *KRAS* p.G12R mutations (both of which are typical of adenomatoid odontogenic tumors) are absent in adenoid ameloblastomas ([J Oral Pathol Med 2021;50:1067](34549835))* Based on limited data, beta catenin mutations, particularly p.Ser33Cys, p.Gly34Arg and p.Ser37Phe, were observed in 4 of 9 patients ([Mod Pathol 2022;35:1562](35840721))

Sample pathology report

* Posterior mandible, right, incisional biopsy:
  + Adenoid ameloblastoma, 1.5 cm

Differential diagnosis

* [Ameloblastoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaameloblastoma.html):
  + Columnar cells with palisading, hyperchromatic nuclei of basal cells+ No hard tissue formation is present* [Adenomatoid odontogenic tumor](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaadenomatoid.html):
    + Epithelium may appear nodular, trabecular or cribriform with duct-like structures+ Amyloid deposits may be present+ Enclosed in thick capsule; radiographically often well defined and associated with impacted maxillary canines* [Calcifying cystic odontogenic tumor](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic.html):
      + Ameloblastic epithelium and ghost cells+ Lacks whorls, duct-like structures and cribriform architecture* [Dentinogenic ghost cell tumor](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxilladentinogenicghost.html):
        + Ameloblastic-like areas with palisading of basaloid cells+ Admixed ghost cells: anucleate epithelial cells with pale, cleared cytoplasm+ Lacks whorls, duct-like structures and cribriform architecture

Additional references

* [WHO Classification of Tumours Editorial Board: Head and Neck Tumours, 5th Edition, 2024](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/9283245148/pathologyoutl-20)
